Sosefina needs a loan of WST $1500 to purchase timber, nail and iron roofing to enlarge and renovate her work-shop house.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 700 talas or US $292 per week) to improve the general living conditions of her family.

Sosefina joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral.  This is Sosefina's second loan with SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase timber, nails and iron roofing to renovate and enlarge her work-shop house

loans.name: Yenny Cecilia

texts.es:
La sala de la casa de Yenny Cecilia C. M. es el lugar donde esta emprendedora de 27 años de edad tiene su negocio de video juegos desde hace un año, el cual se ha convertido en fuente de sustento importante para su ella y su familia, pues aunque su esposo trabaja en algunas oportunidades debe pasar algunos días en la casa por la falta de oportunidades. 

Yenny se siente orgullosa de contribuir en su hogar y espera en el futuro crecer su negocio para poder brindarle a su hija un mejor futuro. 

Por ahora necesita de un préstamo para construir un local y así empezar a ampliarse para hacer realidad su sueño.
texts.en:
The living room of Yenny Cecilia C. M.' home is the place where this 27 year-old entrepreneur has been running her video games business for one year.  It has become an important source of support for herself and her family because, although her husband works, he sometimes has to spend  days at home when there is a lack of opportunities.

Yenny feels proud that she is able to contribute to her household and hopes, in the future, to grow her business so that she can provide her daughter with a better future.

Right now, Yenny needs a loan to build business premises so that she can start expanding her business and make her dream come true.

loans.use: to build business premises

loans.name: Lecibel

texts.en:
Lecibel E. is from the village of Guinitan, Pagalungan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 34 years old, married and has 5 school-aged children. Lecibel owns and operates a specialized retail store, buying and selling ready-to-wear clothing and shoe products, making snacks such as chicharon (fried pork rinds) and making garlands and gift bags in the local community. Lecibel has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2011, Lecibel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lecibel is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products such as blouses and t-shirts. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Lecibel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional clothing items.

location.town: Guinitan, Pagalungan, Cagayan de Oro City

loans.name: Sauya

texts.en:
Sauya is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kasubi in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children.  Sauya has a business of selling hand bags for ladys, which she has had for two years.         

To help expand her business, Sauya has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more hand bags for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Sauya hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for herself.  In the future, Sauya hopes to own a retail shop.

loans.use: to purchase more hand bags for resale

loans.name: Forctina

texts.en:
Forctina, a single mother of five children, four of whom are below the age of 15, was born on June 18, 1977. The family lives in a six-room apartment at the Elemighong quarter in the Belo Subdivision of Cameroon. Foctina's greatest problems were that she did not attain a primary school education and that she needed business capital to take care of her children. The search for business capital was addressed by the encouragement to join the GHAPE program by women who were already GHAPE members in her community. A member since 2009, Forctina took her first loan of 50,000FCFA to buy Irish potatoes to sell. She says sales were very lucrative, enabling her to repay the loan with no problem and also pay her children's tuition fees.

Forctina is now requesting her second loan from GHAPE to buy five bags of potatoes for 23,000FCFA per bag; she will use 10,000FCFA from her savings to pay for the transportation of her products to the Belo weekly market. She is confident of business success due to her many customers who are grateful to have the potatoes at their doorsteps for very reasonable prices. Forctina appreciates working with GHAPE because of their low interest rates and very manageable repayment methods.

About GHAPE

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust with its clients.

loans.use: to buy Irish potatoes for resale.

loans.name: Cristilita

texts.en:
Cristilita works hard to support her family. Cristilita is married and has a restaurant business in the Philippines.

Cristilita requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to purchase meat, fish and other ingredients to sell in her restaurant.

Cristilita has been in this business for 15 years now.

In the future, Cristilita would like to save enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: To purchase meat, fish and other ingredients to sell in her carenderia

loans.name: Jarkynbubu's Group

texts.en:
Jarkynbubu is the leader of this group. She is 37 and married to a driver. Together with her husband she is raising three sons, who are all at school. Four years ago, with an initial investment of 3000 soms, Jarkynbubu started providing sewing services. At the moment her business runs well, and she earns about 18,000 soms per month. Jarkynbubu applied for a loan because she needs additional funds to expand the business. She wants to buy fabrics and a new sewing machine. In the future she wants to buy a big house.

Where Did This Loan Come From?

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our lending team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics and a sewing machine.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
39-year-old Helen earns a living through farming. She is married and has 5 children. The oldest child is 12 while the youngest is only 2.

Helen started farming 8 years ago. She grows rice crops and vegetables. She sells her harvest at her town's market. Helen works hard to help provide their household needs and send her children to school. She applied for a loan to purchase seedlings and fertilizers.

Helen is hoping that her farming business will grow. She also hopes for her children to finish college someday and have bright futures.

loans.use: to purchase seedlings and fertilizers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to add more food products to her store

loans.name: Milton

texts.en:
Milton is a twenty-eight-year-old married man with two children.  He owns a semi-permanent house in Kasese, Uganda. The responsibility of looking after the family is vested in him and his desire is to educate his children up to university. 

Milton has been selling shoes and clothes for fifteen years.  He got his initial capital from selling coffee. His hardship is high commodity prices that lead to low demand and his vision is having a boutique and building a permanent house for residence.  Milton needs this loan to buy clothes and shoes to sell.

loans.use: buy clothes and shoes to sell

loans.name: Dickson

texts.en: Dickson is a hardworking, 29-year-old businessman. He is married and blessed with one child who goes to school. For the past 5 years, he has been operating a butcher shop to make ends meet. He supplements income from this venture with the earnings he makes from his retail shop. He wants, in the next 5 years, to have a big hotel. He is requesting a loan of 40000 Kenya shillings to buy sugar, rice and sodas. Thanks to Faulu Kenya he is now able to save.

loans.use: to buy sugar, rice and sodas

loans.name: Domingo

texts.en:
Domingo is 31 years old and lives in Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur, Philippines. He is married with three school-aged children. 

Domingo owns and operates a retail store to support his family. He has been selling grocery items, school and office supplies, a few hardware products and other items for over 3 years. The couple are known for their good characters as community members. Approximately, he earns a total of 2,500 PHP a month. To further enhance his business, he requested a loan of PHP 5,000 from GDMPC to purchase additional inventory.

Domingo became a member of GDMPC recently. This is his first loan transaction made in the cooperative. In the future, Domingo hopes to sustain his store and expand his business. He dreams of giving his children a good education and plans to double his time to attain this.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory.

loans.name: Carlos

texts.es: El señor Carlos  es un cliente nuevo, vino por recomendación de Su padre que  es un cliente antiguo de la institución,  Carlos tiene como oficio el de técnico electricista el aprendió el oficio de su padre al igual que sus dos hijos desarrolla la misma actividad  hace mas de treinta años, Carlos  actualmente tiene un contrato con una empresa constructora en el centro de la ciudad, el todavía vive con sus Papas pero muy pronto se independizara y vivirá en la ciudad de el alto porque se compro una casita como terreno en la zona  de ventilla el destino del crédito será para la compra de material eléctrico como ser cables de toda medida y en grandes cantidades, enchufes y cajitas, es un joven trabajador con ganas de superación, agradecido con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en:
Sr. Carlos is a new client who came on the recommendation of his father, a longtime client of Emprender.  Carlos is an electrician and learned the trade from his father.  In addition, Carlos’ brother is also in the same line of work and all of them have been in this trade for more than 30 years.  Carlos currently has a contract with a construction firm in the central part of the city.  He still lives at home with his parents, but plans to become independent soon and move to the city of El Alto because he wants to buy a small house and some land in the District of Ventilla.  

This loan will be used to buy electrical supplies such as cables of all sizes and in large quantities, sockets, and electrical boxes.  Carlos is a hardworking young man who has the desire to succeed.  He is grateful to Emprender for the support it has provided.

loans.use: to buy electrical supplies.

loans.name: Algie

texts.en: Algie is 19 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is single. He is providing motorcycle or habal-habal services. He has had this business for 1 year. He requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy tools & pay for gasoline. Algie is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Algie hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy tools & pay for gasoline

loans.name: Maidash's Group

texts.en:
Maidash is the leader of this group. She is 54 and married to a farmer. The family earns money a livelihood by reselling livestock after fattening them. Maidash also sells milk; she sells about 10 liters a day. At the moment, the family needs money to purchase feed for livestock so Maidash applied for the loan. In the future she plans to increase the number of livestock because she wants to leave a good inheritance to her children.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase feed for livestock.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen wants a loan to buy fertilizers for his banana plantation. Aged 44, he hails from the Kyenjojo District and is a widower with one 24-year-old child with whom he lives in a semi-permanent house. Having started with planting one acre of bananas on the land that was inherited from his father, he has expanded to 6 acres and he dreams of building a permanent house.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for the banana plantation

loans.name: Eva Rosa

texts.es:
Eva de 55 años, empezó con una tienda de víveres hace 1 año atrás porque en el sector no había tiendas, además se ayuda vendiendo productos yambal.

Una mujer muy fuerte trabaja de lunes a domingo de 8am hasta las 7pm. Gracias a Dios Eva no ha tenido ningún problema de salud ni de delincuencias. Eva cría solo a su hijo debido a que su esposo trabajo en un barco y sale de viaje por largos tiempos. Ella desea comprar con el prestamo arroz, bebidas, granos, aceite etc. 

Su sueño que desea alcanzar es poder mejorar su vivienda para poder vivir más tranquila con su familia.
texts.en:
Eva, 55, started a convenience store one year ago because there were no other stores in the area.  Moreover, she was helped through her sales of Yanbal cosmetic products.

She is a very strong woman who works Monday to Sunday, from 8 a.m. until 7 p.m. Thankfully, Eva has not had any problems such as issues regarding her health or criminal activity.  She raised her son alone because her husband worked on a boat and was away for long periods of time. She wants to use the loan to buy rice, drinks, grains, oil, etc. 

Her dream is to be able to make improvements on her house so she can live more comfortably with her family.

loans.use: to buy rice, drinks, grains, oil, etc.

loans.name: Delfina

texts.es:
Delfina, D.  40 años D. edad, esta casada con Dionicio D. 41 años, con quien tiene 5 hermosos hijos. Juntos habitan en su casa propia ubicado en el distrito D. Pichari. Para delfina, el factor más relevante es “la creatividad y la perseverancia continua”; desD. luego lo implementó, cuanto tuvo sus primeras cosechas, pero ella quería ambicionar a más, para que D. esa manera brinD. seguridad a su familia. Actualmente se dedica al cultivo y producción D. café, actividad que le esta yendo bien, puesto que sus compradores potenciales se sienten muy satisfechos por la calidad del producto agrícola que los ofrece. Normalmente trabaja en compañía D. su familia, y juntos hacen un buen equipo D. trabajo, además asegura que minimiza en gastos, ya que no necesita D. mano D. obra D. terceras personas. Usualmente su producto D. café los venD. en los centros D. acopio del distrito D. Pichari. 
Este será su segundo credito con MFP, por lo que ella se compromete en cancelar puntualmente el pago D. sus cuotas. Con los 1,500 nuevos soles, lo invertirá en la limpieza D. las malezas D. su parcela agrícola
texts.en:
40-year-old Delfina is married to 41-year-old Dionicio with whom she has five beautiful children.  They live together in their own home which is located in Pichari district.  For Delfina, the most important factor is "continual creativity and perseverance" and she implemented this with her first harvests.  However, she wanted to achieve more so that she could proviD. her family with security.  She currently grows and produces coffee.  Her business is doing well as her potential buyers feel very satisfied with the quality of the produce that she offers them.  Delfina normally works with her family and they work well as a team.  In addition, she says that it minimizes expenses as she doesn't need labor from other people.  Delfina usually sells her coffee at the storage warehouses in Pichari district.

This will be Delfina's second loan from MFP and she pledges to make her repayments on time.  She will use the 1,500 soles to invest in clearing the weeds from her plot of farmland.

loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies for weeding her land

loans.name: Vecinos Responsables Group

texts.es:
La Sra. Manuela tiene 32 años D. edad, tiene 5 hijos D. los cuales 2 aun son menores D. edad, desD. muy joven se dedicó a trabajar ya que debía mantener a sus hijos sola.
El,a inició trabajando en casas, poco a poco y juntando el dinero que le pagaban juntó para comprar su carrito mazamorrero, pudo dejar D. trabajar en casa y empezó con su negocio D. venta D. mazamorra, poco a poco pudo salir adelante, hoy en día venD. comida, le va bien pero le gustaría contar con un restaurante y poder atender mas clientes.
Gracias a su trabajo ha logrado brindar a sus hijos educación y lo necesario para vivir como alimentos y ropa.
El préstamo recibido lo invertirá en la compra D. insumos para la preparación D. menú.
texts.en:
Manuela is 32 years old and has five children two of which are still minors.  Since a very young age she’s worked because she’s had to support her children by herself.  She started out working in houses gradually saving money she was paid and was able to buy her little cart to sell ‘mazamorras’ [a jelly-like dessert, purple as one of its main ingredients: the purple maize] and was able to stop working in houses and start her business selling mazamorras.  

Gradually she was able to make progress and today she sells food.  She does well but she’d like to have a restaurant and to take care of more customers.  Thanks to her work she’s been able to proviD. her children with education and what’s needed to live like food and clothing.  The loan she received will be used to buy ingredients to prepare her dishes.

loans.use: to buy food preparation ingredients.

loans.name: Cherryrose

texts.en:
Cherryrose is 24 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 2 children. 
Cherryrose has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks & beverages. She has had this business for 2 years. She requested a loan for PHP 9,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages .
Cherryrose has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Cherryrose hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages

loans.name: María Guadalupe

texts.es: María Guadalupe de 57 años de edad, habita en casa propia junto con su grupo familiar el cual está conformado por su esposo, nieta y suegra de 57, 15 y 85 años respectivamente. Se dedica a la venta de diferentes productos tales como: ropa, cosméticos, controles,  lámparas, etc. Esta actividad la realiza de forma  ambulante junto con la ayuda de su esposo. Tiene muchos años de dedicarse a este negocio y gracias a su arduo trabajo ha sabido mantenerlo activo. Muchas personas la prefieren por ser una mujer trabajadora, honesta y amable. Todos los días sale desde tempranas horas para mostrar los diferentes productos a sus clientes que cada día son más. Últimamente ha estado pensando en la forma de hacer crecer su negocio ya que la situación económica cada día es más difícil y no encuentra otra forma de hacer dinero para dar a su familia lo necesario. Esto la ha llevado a solicitar este crédito a INTEGRAL   para comprar variedad de artículos tales como: prendas de vestir, cosméticos, y de más productos que sean atractivos  para los clientes ya que su meta es mejorar sus niveles de venta y de ingresos de tal forma que pueda tener la oportunidad de accesar a una mejor oportunidad de vida. No pierde las esperanzas que de esta manera su situación va a mejorar.
texts.en:
María Guadalupe is 57, and lives in her own house with her family, consisting of her husband, granddaughter, and mother-in-law, ages 57, 15, and 85 respectively. 

She sells various products, such as clothing, cosmetics, remote controls, lamps etc.. She works as a street vendor, with her husband's help.

She has been working in this business for many years, and thanks to her hard work, she has been able to keep herself busy. Many people prefer her because she is a hard-working, honest, and friendly woman. She goes out every day from an early hour to display her various products to her customers, who are more numerous every day. 

Lately she has been thinking about a way of increasing her business, as the economic situation is more difficult every day, and she isn't finding another way to make money to provide her family with the necessities. 

This has led her to apply to Integral for this loan, in order to buy a variety of goods, such as articles of clothing, cosmetics, and other products that may be attractive to her customers. Her goal is to improve her sales and income, so that she can have the chance to access better opportunities in life. 

She doesn't lose hope that in this way, her situation is going to improve.

loans.use: To buy articles of clothing, cosmetics, remote controls, and lamps.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha is 69 years old, married to David, and they are blessed with six children. She has been a private school director for the past fifteen years with a monthly income of Kes 25,000 which she uses to support her family.

She is applying for a first loan with KADET Ltd  after being introduced by an existing KADET customer. Martha will use the loan to build more classrooms. With the anticipated profit from the business she will further expand the school. 

Her hopes and dreams are to open another school.

loans.use: To build more classrooms.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is a 44-year-old businesswoman and a single mother of two children. She has been selling cereals for the past six years, earning a monthly income of KES 20,000 which she uses to support her family.

Janet is applying for her first loan term from KADET LTD after being introduced to KADET by a staff member. She will use the loan to buy dry maize and beans for her business. Janet plans to use the anticipated profit from her business to educate her children. Her hopes and dreams are to buy a piece of land and build a store for her grains.

loans.use: To buy dry maize and beans for sale

loans.name: Humet

texts.en:
Humet is 38 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, who are both currently in school. For the past 28 years, Humet has been working hard to manage her restaurant, which sells cooked food. 

To help expand her business, Humet has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more food for the restaurant to sell, and will help Humet to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Humet hopes that in the future she will be able to expand the restaurant into a hotel. 

Humet is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Humet who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more food to sell in her restaurant

loans.name: Akouegnon 1 Group

texts.fr: AKOUEGNON 1 est un groupe composé de trois personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. Afin d'élever le niveau de leur activité, ce groupe sollicite pour la quatrième fois l'appui financier de ALIDé. La représentante du groupe, du nom de Cécile (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) est âgée de 39 ans. Cécile n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Cécile est mariée à un chauffeur du nom de Jules. Le couple a deux enfants, tous scolarisés et un à leur charge. Cécile vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Les diverses charges du ménage sont supportées par Cécile et son mari. Pour cette raison, Cécile vend des perles et des sacs  depuis six ans environ, ce qui lui permet de mieux faire face aux besoins de ses enfants et à leur éducation. Cécile s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaire et son revenu, Cécile sollicite ensemble avec les membres du groupe AKOUEGNON 1, un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les crédits reçus antérieurement ont été bien remboursés.

loans.use: Acheter des perles et des sacs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Beth would like to buy cement and concrete to make Bricks/blocks

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort sells fried fish in her community. She buys the fish in cartons from the harbour and fries them for sale. She wants to buy more cartons of fish for frying to supply her customers. She is seeking a Kiva loan of $700.00 to enable her to do so.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Ángela

texts.en:
Angela has her business in the market where she sells plastic items. Angela began her business with money that she saved when she immigrated to Spain. At first she sold only plastic items. Now she continues to offer these products along with the sale of clothing and lingerie. She hopes to sell a variety of things and buy a vitrine in which to display the merchandise. Angela is sure that with these new products, her sales will increase and this will allow her to continue growing her business and to make larger investments. She is 41 years old, has two children who are studying, and has a cement house. Her children help her in her business. She is very organized in her business and has faith that with her earnings she will improve the quality of life for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

Angela tiene su negocio en el mercado donde vende artículos plásticos. Angela empezó su negocio con un dinero que ahorro cuando emigro a España. Al principio solo vendía artículos plásticos. Ahora continúa ofreciendo este producto junto con venta de ropa y lencería. Angela aspira vender artículos de varios y comprar una vitrina para mostrar la mercadería. Angela esta convencida que con estos nuevos productos sus ventas se incrementaran y le permitirá seguir ampliando su negocio y realizar mayores inversiones. Angela tiene 41 años, dos hijos que estudian tiene vivienda de cemento sus hijos la apoyan en el negocio. Es muy organizada en el negocio ,tiene fe que con sus ganancias mejorara la calidad de vida de su familia.

loans.use: To diversify her inventory

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores Lopes Matin weaves Mayan textiles for belts, collars, purses and postcards, and she also makes custom jewelry to sell to tourists.  She knows her business and how to prepare for the seasonal fluctuations and other challenges that come her way. 
Dolores was born 50 years ago and still lives in the same house where her family has always lived.  She sits on the earthen floor on a piece of cardboard weaving a bright yellow and very long narrow fabric which will be cut up to make postcards. She had never had her own stall or store to sell her crafts but does her work to order for others who will then sell on the street or in their stalls.This very demure woman looks frail, but she has a heart and smile as big as the world. After Hurricane Stan destroyed a local church, she opened her home to those that needed a new place to worship and recover from the devastation. The fact that the worshipers are of a different denomination than she is makes no difference to her.  Although Dolores is single and has no children, she opens her heart and home for those in need.  She also shares her home as a sanctuary for a friend whose husband drank too much and beat her but remains responsible for raising and supporting 6 children. 
Dolores started out her business with a little money from her father to buy material. But when someone stole everything she had, she started using credit to buy materials to jump start her business. She is now a member of the women’s group called “Shalom” where she has been an outstanding member for 4 years. She will use this loan to buy more material to make more weaving which she sells to other women.

loans.use: She will use this loan to buy more material to make more weavings which she sells to other women.

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Mrs. Imelda R. has sold new and used clothing for more than 20 years. "This business is the only source of income for my family ; my daughter works with me. I thank God that this business has allowed me to support my daughter and give her an education. I would like to invest in winter merchandise, for which I am requesting a loan of $500."

Translated from Spanish by Rosario McFaull, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Imelda R. tiene ya más de 20 años dedicándose a la venta de ropa usada y nueva. Este negocio es la fuente de ingreso de mi familia en el trabajos mi hija y yo. Gracias a dios este negocio me ha dado para sacar a mi hija delante y darle los estudio necesario, quiero invertir le mas de mercancía de temporada de frió. Por el cual solicito un préstamo de $500.00 dlls para la compra de mercancía.

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: San

texts.en:
Mrs. San C., aged 34, raises ducks and sells the eggs, earning $5 per day. Her husband, aged 43, is a fisherman, earning less than $1 per day. They have two children, one who is a student and one who is married and living away from home.

In order to expand her business, she would like to request a loan of $1,200 to purchase more ducks in order to generate additional income for her family. She plans to use any remaining loan funds to purchase feed for the additional ducks. In the future, she plans to reinvest to expand her business further and fund her children’s education.

loans.use: To purchase additional ducks and duck feed to expand her duck  business.

loans.name: Xocomil Group

texts.es:
ComUnidad Xocomil (ComUnidad is a term that Friendship Bridge uses to name Communal Banks) is formed by a group of happy, entrepreneurial, united and pioneering women. This ComUnidad is one of the oldest in Friendship Bridge.

This group of women are requesting their 16th loan with the institution, despite the adversities that are presented to indigenous women in the rural areas of Guatemala. They have maintained themselves united for approximately 7 years, consolidating an unequaled friendship based on honesty and work ethic. The women of Xocomil are an example to Guatemalan society because they were one of the pioneers when they first applied for a loan almost a decade ago – a situation that had never occurred before.

Many of these women worked as housekeepers in wealthy homes in the capital city or in the homes of their relatives. Others grew up as weavers, lending their services to more developed businesses as cheap labor. These artisans also worked weaving their own products per individual requests, but in a very small scale. They earned enough to cover their living expenses, however, since they united with Friendship Bridge, their businesses have prospered and they have turned into successful businesswomen.

In ComUnidad Xocomil, one can find women that work in different economic sectors. For example, six of them weave beautiful huipiles (traditional indigenous Guatemalan dress); three of them work buying and selling traditional clothes such as skirts, aprons, sashes and blouses; three others sell breakfasts, lunches and dinners in the market and for house delivery; while another three cut up chickens and pigs and sell them in the market. One of them makes and sells tortillas in her own locale, while two others have a bakery.

The women will invest the loan in the purchase of thread for the production of huipiles and the purchase of chickens to quarter and sell in the market, while other women will buy blouses and aprons for their respective trade. The women that have a bakery will buy flour and utensils for the production of bread.

These women have been examples of the positive impact that microfinancing institutions have on the lives of women. Thanks to Friendship Bridge, they are full of hopes and dreams. Many of them aspire to purchase a plot of land to construct a house for their children or expand their small homes. They also hope that their children graduate from high school so that they do not have to experience what these women lived, an illiteracy that deprived them of many rights and advantages. The dreams of these women are consolidated with each loan and investment that they bring to their businesses and families. Help them maintain this hope.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

La ComUnidad Xocomil (ComUnidad es un término que utiliza Friendship Bridge para nombrar a los Bancos Comunales) está conformada por un grupo de mujeres alegres, emprendedoras, unidas y pioneras. Esta ComUnidad es una de las más antiguas en Friendship Bridge.

Este grupo de señoras están solicitando su 16to préstamo con la institución, a pesar de las adversidades que se les presenta a mujeres indígenas en las áreas rurales de Guatemala. Ellas se han mantenido unidas por aproximadamente 7 años consolidando una amistad inigualable que está basada en honestidad y trabajo. Las mujeres del Xocomil son un ejemplo a la sociedad Guatemalteca porque ellas fueron una de las pioneras al solicitar su crédito hace casi una década. Una situación que antes no sucedía

Muchas de estas señoras trabajaron como empleadas domésticas en casas de gente adinerada en la capital o en casa de sus parientes. Otras crecieron como tejedoras prestando sus servicios a empresarios más desarrollados como mano de obra barata. También, las estas artesanas trabajaban tejiendo sus propios tejidos a pedidos individuales, pero en muy pequeña escala. Ellas ganaban lo suficiente para cubrir sus gastos de vida. Sin embargo, desde que se unieron a Friendship Bridge sus negocios han prosperado y se han vuelto en empresarias exitosas.

En la Comunidad Xocomil se puede encontrar a señoras que trabajan en distintas áreas económicas. Por ejemplo, seis de ellas son tejedoras de hermosos huipiles (trajes tradicionales indígenas Guatemaltecos); tres trabajan en la compra y venta de ropa tradicional como faldas, delantales, fajas y blusas; tres señoras venden desayunos, almuerzos y cenas en el mercado y a domicilio; mientras que otras tres destazan pollos y cerdos y los venden en el mercado; una de ellas prepara y vende tortillas en su propio local y dos señoras tienen una panadería.

El crédito va a ser invertido por las señoras en la compra de hilo para la producción de huipiles, compra de pollos para destazarlos y venderlos en el mercado, otras señoras van a usar el crédito para comprar blusas y delantales para su respectiva venta. Las señoras que tienen una panadería van a comprar harina y utensilios para la producción de pan.

Estas señoras han sido ejemplos del impacto positivo que tiene las microfinanzas en la vida de las mujeres. Ellas, gracias a Friendhsip Bridge, están llenas de esperanzas y sueños. Muchas de ellas aspiran a comprarse un terreno para construir una casa para sus hijos o para ampliar sus pequeñas casas. También aspiran a que sus hijos se gradúen del colegio para que así ellos no tengan que pasar por lo que ellas vivieron, un analfabetismo que las privó de muchos derechos y ventajas. Los sueños de estas señoras se consolida con cada préstamo e inversión que ellas hacen en su negocio y su familias, ayúdenlas a mantener esa esperanza.

loans.use: Purchase thread for the creation of traditional dresses; chickens and pigs to sell in the market; ingredients for the preparation of meals; blouses and aprons for the sale of clothing; and flour and utensils for a bakery.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: she needs the loan to purchase goods

loans.name: Afari

texts.en: Afari G. is a single mother who buys and sells cassava, corn, and plantains to local villagers. People buy these products to make “fufu,” a very popular dish in Ghana, which is made by cooking cassava and plantains and then pounding them together in a bowl so that they become a condensed paste. She supports her 5 children and is requesting $525 to buy more cassava and plantains for her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional cassava and plantains for her business.

loans.name: Ndifakulya East A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Edisa B.. She is currently in the business of charcoal sales and is requesting a loan to expand to bulk selling. Edisa is 35 years old and is married. Her husband is a carpenter. She has 3 children ranging from age 4 to 14 and her children go to school. Each week, Edisa makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land and build a house. Edisa has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Edisa is joined in her small group by Haawa N., Zahara N., Fatuma N., and Haawa K.. Haawa N. has a business in charcoal selling and wants to construct a charcoal store and add more stock. Zahara N. is currently operating a business in clothing sales and wants a loan to add to her business. Fatuma N. operates a carpentry business and wants to boost business. Haawa K. is currently in the business of running a beauty salon and is requesting a loan to purchase more hair oils and chemicals.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal in large quantities

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To continue stocking store with different products

loans.name: Sandra Guadalupe

texts.es:
Sandra started her business because she needed to help her husband cover the family expenses. They have a newborn child, which means they have to buy many essentials, such as diapers, milk, food, as well as pay for other household expenses. Her husband’s low income makes it difficult to purchase these necessities. She therefore started her clothing business 3 years ago, when her baby was born because she immediately realized that the expenses would grow. There was no other alternative other than getting a job, but she wanted to get a job that would allow her to be close to her son. Thanks to this business, she can balance both working and looking after her child, which puts her at ease.

She is requesting a loan of $575.00 USD, which she will repay in 6 months. This loan will allow her to purchase more merchandise for the season and offer her customers a greater selection of products.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Sandra inició el negocio porque tiene que ayudar a su esposo con los gastos de la casa, ya que tienen un bebe recién nacido y son muchas las cosas que hay que comprar entre pañales, leche, alimentos y además los gastos de la casa; cosas que con el sueldo de su esposo no alcanza para poder comprarlas. Comenzó hace tres años con la venta de ropa cuando nació el bebe, ya que de inmediato se dio cuenta que los gastos iban a ser grandes y no hubo otra alternativa que comenzar a trabajar pero tenia que ser un trabajo que le permitiera estar al lado de su hijo. Gracias a este negocio puede mezclar ambos y no hay problema además que le permite estar mas tranquila.

Solicita un préstamo por US $575 que pagara en 6 meses. Este crédito le va a servir para poder comprar más mercancía de temporada y tener bien surtido para ofrecer variedad a su clientela.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase of materials for a small cafeteria.

loans.name: Thi Cuc

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thi Cuc (ID number: 050043) is 34 years old. This is the first time she applies for loan. She wants to borrow 2,006,000VND (approximately 125USD) to buy more food for the chickens and fish that she is breeding. She also makes canvas bags to obtain a stable income for her family. Her husband works as a construction worker for additional income. Her family's daily income is about 100,000VND (approximately 6.50USD). She has 3 school-going children. She has never borrowed from any where else.

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Cúc (MS: 050043), năm nay 34 tuổi. Chị tham gia vay lần một. Chị vay 2.006.000 VND về mua cám chăn nuôi gà, cá. Bản thân chị đi làm bao tải co thu nhập thường xuyên cho gia đình. Chồng chị đi làm xây dựng giúp gia đình có thêm thu nhập. Anh chị có 3 con hiện còn đang đi học Mức thu nhập của gia đình chị 100.000 VND. Gia đình chị chưa tham gia vay vốn ở đâu.

loans.use: Animal breeding

loans.name: Jean Claude

texts.en:
Greetings from Rwamagana in Rwanda! Claude is 36 years old, married with four children and one adopted child orphaned in the 1994 Genocide.

In 2005, he started a small pub selling various local drinks and beverages in the center after accessing a loan of $200 from Vision Finance Company. He also operates his own shop selling various items including sugar, soap, salt, paraffin for lighting houses in rural areas, matchboxes, rice, cassava flour, cooking oil, beans, and sorghum. Claude employs three people to help him run the businesses and earns about $150 per month. He is applying for a loan of $925 to increase his stock and expand his pub.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Husna

texts.en:
Husna is 36 years old. She is married with 4 children, ages 14, 11, 9, and 5. She has been a clothing seller since 2004. Every day she works from 8:00 AM to 10:00 PM at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $550 from her sales.

Husna now requests a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business

loans.name: Naimkhoja

texts.en:
Naimkhoja N. is 29 years old. He is married with two adorable kids. For almost 2 years Naimkhoja has been working in the local market of the city, selling wheat, green gram, buckwheat and peas. These legumes are very popular in Tajikistan, as they can be cooked in soups or made into cereals, and both are very nourishing, healthy and tasty. This business is very stable and generates the only income for his large family, as Naimkhoja lives with his parents.

Today, he is requesting a loan to increase stock, by purchasing more grains for selling. Naimkhoja thanks all for their support and promises to pay the loan on time.

loans.use: To purchase more grains to increase stock

loans.name: Muminboi

texts.en:
Muminboi is a married man and has 4 kids. He is a craftsman and makes traditional baskets out of twigs. His wife also helps him in making baskets. They collect twigs in fields all the time and then all together they make baskets. He also teaches his kids the secrets of his mastership. 

He wants to borrow money because he also sells other home stuff and wants to offer more products for sale.

loans.use: Expanding his business

loans.name: Volodymir

texts.en:
Volodymir is married and has two small children. A few years ago, he was laid off and couldn’t find a job. He decided to invest his savings into a small business: using his car as a taxi. Volodymir helps his clients get around, not only within the city limits but to other cities as well. He has loyal clients, which makes his business more and more successful. His daily gross income is 180-200 UAH. The car has been equipped to use a special low cost gas to save money on fuel.

Volodymir is requesting a loan of 5000 UAH to fix his car. After he fixes his car, he will be able to take home a regular income and better provide for his familys needs.

loans.use: to fix his car

loans.name: Toshmamad

texts.en:
Toshmamad B. is 50 years old. He is married and the father of 6 children. Toshmamad is a hardworking and enterprising man who constantly tries to do things better and improve day after day. He works hard in his fields, where he spends as much time as possible providing the necessary care, fertilizing his land and spraying to prevent diseases that might affect his yields. Toshmamad needs tools and fertilizers to continue his difficult work of tending his crops so that they can be taken to the capital city for sale. That's why he's applying for a loan of 4000 Somoni ($1,200) for the term of 12 months. Together we can reach out our hands to help Toshmamad!  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road, the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and the birthplace of the great Persian poet Rudaki and the most famous Islamic philosopher Ibn Sina (Avicenna). The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need.

loans.use: Purchasing of mineral fertilizer, plus fuels and lubricants for tools

loans.name: Kayunga-Margret Mugumya Group

texts.en:
Margret M. (in the back on the right) is 40 years old and a widow. She has 4 children who are all in school. Margret sells cereals in Pallisa town. She mainly targets schools because they make bulk purchases. Margret purchases her stock directly from farmers at a fair price, enabling her to earn a profit of approximately 25% of sales.

The loan is enabling Margret replenish her stock of maize, beans, and rice. Her dream is to open up a chain of outlets in the neighbouring towns. As a widow, this business has enabled her sustain her family single-handedly. She hopes that with a positive turn of events in her business dream, her children will never lack.

loans.use: Purchase maize, beans and rice for re-sale

loans.name: Sinignèssigui Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe  Sinignèssigui sont mariés, âgés de  25 à 65 ans et mères de 5 enfants en moyenne. Ils vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le quartier Bounoukobougou de la préfecture de Yanfolila (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes sont partenaires de Soro Yiriwaso  depuis 5 ans et font le petit commerce de condiments alimentaires et de céréales. Elles sont à leur neuvième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe) et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien  remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt les femmes comptent acheter, 200 kg  d’arachide pour préparer de la pâte d’arachide, 50 kg d’oignons frais, 50 kg de graines de néré pour la préparation du soumbala, 500kg de maïs, 200kg de sorgho et 100kg de petit mil. Elles s’approvisionnent auprès des paysans producteurs et effectuent leurs ventes en détail au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle essentiellement constituée de femmes.   
Ces activités permettent aux femmes du groupe Sinignèssigui de réaliser en   moyenne une marge bénéficiaire mensuelle de 50.000FCFA. Ce qui leurs permet de rembourser l’échéance du prêt et de faire face à certains besoins du foyer (santé, éducation, habillement…etc.)
texts.en:
The members of the Sinignèssigui group are married, aged between 25 and 65, and have an average of five children each. They live in traditional extended families in the Bounoukobougou neighborhood of the Yanfolila prefecture (Mali’s third administrative region). The women have been partners of Soro Yiriwaso for five years and have a small business selling spices and cereals. They are on their ninth solidarity loan (group loan) and all previous loans were fully repaid. The women plan to use this loan to buy 200 kg of peanuts for making peanut butter, 50 kg of fresh onions, 50 kg of néré seeds for preparing soumbala, 500 kg of corn, 200 kg of sorghum and 100 kg of millet. They get their supplies from local producers and sell them at retail for cash or credit to a clientele consisting mainly of women. The business allows the women of the Sinignèssigui group to make an average profit of CFA 50,000/month. With this they are able to repay the loan and meet some of the needs of their household (health, education, clothing, etc.).

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various food items

loans.name: Joaquin Alberto

texts.es: Joaquín Alberto M. López tiene 46 años, esta casado. Y tiene 3 hijos. Todos sus hijos estudian. La actividad económica de Don Joaquín es joyero. Hace más de 20 años que se dedica a este negocio. Don Joaquín tiene el propósito de ampliar su negocio ya que este es muy pequeño y se encuentra en su casa de habitación. El financiamiento es para capital de trabajo por lo que necesita la materia prima para la elaboración de las joyas. Su sueño es de poseer otro negocio y que sus hijos lo administren. la cantidad solicitada es de C$ 7.000 córdobas a un plazo de 12 meses.
texts.en:
Joaquín Alberto M. López is 46 years old and married with three children. All of his children attend school. For more than 20 years Joaquín has been a jeweler. His plans for his business include expanding it, seeing the business is very small and is run out of his home. The loan requested will be used for working capital, which Joaquín needs to purchase materials for making jewelry. Joaquín dreams of owning a second business and hopes his children one day will manage it. He is requesting 7,000 córdobas [about US $350], which he will pay back in 12 months.

Translated from Spanish by Todd M. Anderson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Jean Claude

texts.fr:
Monsieur Jean Claude B. est un  célibataire de 21 ans qui vit  chez ses parents  dans le quartier Torakabougou Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Après avoir fini ses études secondaires en Comptabilité, Monsieur Jean Claude décide de mener  une activité génératrice de revenus. Après avoir tenté plusieurs telle l’achat vente de tissus, il opta finalement pour les  jeux téléchargés. Il fît ses premiers pas  auprès d’un de ses  amis.
Avec une expérience de 3 ans, Monsieur Jean Claude B. arrive à bien s’en sortir car maîtrise son activité et devient la coqueluche des jeunes de la ville. Les week-end,  congés de Noël, de pâques et les grandes vacances sont les périodes  intenses pour son activité.
Pour améliorer son entreprise, il décida d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel.
Il compte  acheter avec ce prêt,  1 téléviseur pour les jeux téléchargés et 4 cassettes à  Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali). Ses clients sont généralement les jeunes du quartier. 
Avec ce prêt, monsieur Jean Claude B. compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 20 000 FCFA.
 Dans les années à venir il envisage ouvrir une autre salle de jeux dans un autre quartier de Bougouni.
texts.en:
Mr. Jean Claude B., age 21, is an unmarried man who lives at his parents’ place in the Torakabougou Bougouni district (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After finishing his secondary studies in accounting, he decided to work in an incoming-generating activity. After having tried several kinds of work, such as buying and selling cloth, he finally opted for downloaded games. He made his initial steps with one of his friends.

With three years of experience, Mr. Jean Claude B. is managing to come out of it nicely because he’s mastering his business and becoming the idol of youngsters in town. Weekends, Christmas and Easter holidays, and vacation times are when business is intense.

To improve his enterprise, he decided to join the loan program of the finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which he is now on his first individual loan. He intends to use this loan to buy a television set for downloaded games and four cassettes in Bamako (capital of Mali). His customers are generally young people of the district.

With this loan, he plans to realize a monthly profit of 20,000 francs CFA. In the years to come, he envisions opening another game room in another district of Bougouni.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a television set and four game cassettes

loans.name: Olena

texts.en:
Olena is divorced and raising two children, who are 11 and 6 years old. She owns a small store that sells various construction and finishing materials. Her store is located close to the markets and business area of the city. Good location brings many customers to Olena's store. Her monthly profit is about 6,000 UAH.

Olena has been in this business for 10 years. Being their only source of income, the business helps Olena to raise her children. Olena's goal is to fix up her apartment and improve her living conditions. Olena is an enthusiastic and hard-working person; she believes she can cope with all living problems and difficulties.

Olena would like to borrow 14,000 UAH to purchase 20 doors. Additional profit would help her to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase 20 doors

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: Since 2004 Emmanuel S. has worked as a trader at Shama Junction, selling such goods as plastic bags and frozen fish. He is married with three children and received an education through Junior High School. His wife is also employed as a trader in the area. Emmanuel is responsible for paying for various family essentials, such as water and light bills, and also for providing housekeeping money. His loan will be used to increase his capital to buy more fresh fish for his cold store. He hopes to use his newly gained profits to reinvest back into the business.

loans.use: To buy more fresh fish for his cold store

loans.name: Felix Antonio

texts.es: El Señor  Félix Obando, tiene 43 años de edad, reside en el barrio Laureles Sur en la capital de Managua. Casado su esposa trabajo como tortillera para adquirir otros ingresos, tiene cuatros hijos pero tres son independientes y el menor que esta a su dominio. Iniciaron un proyecto de construcción en su vivienda pero por falta de recursos económicos no lo han culminado. Don Félix se desempeña como maestro de obra por contratos desde hace 8 años. Lo cual se le hace más fácil para la construcción. Sus planes en lo laboral es montar su pequeña compañía. Este es su sexto ciclo, en Afodenic y da las gracias por el apoyo lo cual lograra poner una solera en el patio de su casa comprando los materiales tales como: zinc, perlines, clavos de acero, entre otros materiales.
texts.en:
Mr. Félix Obando is 43 years old and resides in the Laureles Sur neighborhood in the capital of Managua. He is married and his wife works making tortillas for additional income. He has three children, three are independent and the youngest is still in his care.

They began a construction project on their house but they lack the economic resources to complete it. Mr. Félix has worked as a foreman on contracted projects for 8 years. His work plans are to better his small company. This is his sixth cycle with Afodenic and he is thankful for the support, which he will invest in the base construction on his patio and the purchase of materials such as: zinc, steel nails and other materials.

Translated from Spanish by Breanne Kochert, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase construction materials for the construction of a patio on the back of his house.

loans.name: Rustam

texts.ru: Рустам мужчина торгующий на рынке Гафурова запасными частями автомашин и велосипедов.Он получает товар от поставщиков, которые привозят из Китая.Его торговля проходит стабильно, поэтому для поддержки товарооборота Рустам хочет получить повторный кредит.На снимке Рустам в день подачи заявки на займ.Он арендует небольшой ларёк в центре рынка "Фаровон".Рустама удовлетворяют все условия Фонда и он благодарен всем инвесторам за поддержку и финансирование.
texts.en:
Rustam is a vendor at the Gafurova market, where he rents a small stall and sells spare parts for cars and bicycles. The goods come from suppliers who import them from China. His sales have been stable, and to sustain business he would like to take out a new loan. In the photograph Rustam is pictured the day he applied for the loan. Rustam has met all the Fund's conditions and he is grateful for all of the investors' support and financing.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Spare part sales

loans.name: Mariya

texts.en:
Mariya is married. She runs a small business selling women’s clothing in the central market in Vinogradovo, Ukraine. She has been in business for over ten years. She has an enterprising spirit and is very hard-working and persevering. The success she has achieved in her business is a direct result of her efforts and commitment to her work. Presently, Mariya has 25,000 Grivnyas in inventory. Her income is about 3,000 Grivnyas each month.

Mariya would like to obtain a loan of 9,000 Grivnyas to open a new vending facility and stock it with necessary merchandise. Wide selection of clothing items will help her better present the benefits of her products and services to her customers. Mariya tries to avoid copying the inventory of other market vendors. She has built a good reputation for the quality of her products and support services. We believe that her constant quest to improve her business and services will help her achieve continued success and enable her to repay this loan on time.

loans.use: To open a new vending facility and stock it with necessary merchandise

loans.name: Nanga

texts.en:
Nanga was born on the 1971 and is married to a very supportive man. They are blessed with five children, four who are younger than fifteen. She lives in a four room house the Nstualam quarter of Bamenda, Cameroon. Before becoming a member, Nanga underwent surgical operations twice during child birth. She joined GHAPE in 2007 and has since benefited enormously through their help. With her previous loans she succeeded in providing her community with table birds for food and manure for farming.

With the third loan, she plans to buy a motorbike. Her son will be riding the motorbike. She will reinvest part of the profit into her business for expansion. She will also use part for food, clothes, school fees, and hospital bills.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike and fuel

loans.name: Noralita

texts.en:
Noralita B. is a 61-year old widow who manages a rice farm. She started managing the farm last year. She was very sad and now the only thing she wants to do is make the farm productive in honor of her husband who passed away.

However, she needs additional capital to sustain her farm and would like a loan of Php 10,000. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers and chemicals. In this way, she can increase the size of her normal harvest.

Currently, she is connected with the CEVI credit program. She is happy because CEVI provides not just loans but education in how to make her small business grow.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and chemicals

loans.name: Ami

texts.fr: Mme Ami T. est une coiffeuse ambulante dans son village Gamégblé. Née en 1965 et mère de quatre (04) enfants, elle mène cette activité depuis plusieurs années. Elle va de maison en maison et de village en village pour coiffer et teinter les femmes et les enfants. Cette activité lui permet de s’en sortir par les revenus qu’elle en tire. Elle sollicite un apport financier pour acheter les produits qu’elle utilise pour son travail et d’autres matériels de travail.
texts.en:
Ms. Ami T. is an itinerant hairdresser in her village, in Gamégblé. Born in 1965 and the mother of four children, she has been this business for several years. She goes from house to house, and from village to village, to cut or dye the hair of women and children. This business allows her to cope by the revenues she derives from it. Ami is requesting financial participation to buy the products she uses for her work and other work supplies or equipment.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Hairdressing

loans.name: Rita

texts.en: Mrs. Rita N. is a resident of Khokhana-Dobato. Khokhana-Dobato is located in Lalitpur district. It is one of the developing villages of Lalitpur, and most of the people in this region are engaged in agricultural farming. Mrs. N. lives in single-family home with her husband and two children. Her husband, Mr. Bashanta N., works in a government office. She has one son and one daughter. Her son is studying in grade 7, and her daughter is only a year old. Mrs. N. opened her butcher shop two years ago to improve the living standard of her family. She sells chicken and buffalo meat in her shop. Now, due to the increasing demand for meat, she is requesting her first loan of 10,000 NPR to invest in her shop.

loans.use: To invest in her shop

loans.name: Doris

texts.es:
Doris tiene 34 años, es una madre muy empeñada en sacar adelante a sus hijos, vive en su propia casa y tiene 3 niños: Huber de 14, Vanesa de 8 y Ali de 1 año, a los que desea dar unos buenos estudios. Su trabajo es muy poco común y tiene un cierto toque tenebroso, ella construye ataúdes en su propia casa y los tiene guardados para cuando se los soliciten. Doris no tiene miedo de realizar este trabajo y tampoco le importa mucho que su negocio esté frente a la morgue de la ciudad. Pues lo que más le gusta es que su negocio está en su casa y puede atender a sus hijos en el momento que más la necesiten. Lleva 2 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es acomodar los ataúdes de tal forma que no se raspen ni se malogren. Para el futuro espera tener una funeraria para poder vender con más comodidad y brindar otros servicios.
Este es su cuarto préstamo con MFP y al igual como hizo con sus primeros créditos, espera poder pagar a tiempo todas sus cuotas. En su banco comunal es muy alegre y siempre está pendiente de los acuerdos a los que se lleguen en las reuniones. Con los mil nuevos soles solicitados comprará mayor cantidad de madera de buena calidad para realizar nuevos ataúdes.
texts.en:
Doris is 34 years old and a very determined mother when it comes to raising her kids. She lives in her own home with her 3 children: Huber (age 14), Vanesa (age 8), and Ali (age 1). She hopes to provide them with a good education.

Doris is in a line of business that is not very common and can be a bit gloomy. She manufactures coffins in her home and stores them until they are needed. Doris is not afraid of this type of work and doesn’t mind that her business is in front of the city morgue. She has been engaged in this activity for 2 years and believes the most difficult part of her job is making sure the coffins don’t get scraped or fall apart. In the future, she hopes to have her own funeral parlor where she can sell coffins more easily and provide other services.

Doris is requesting her fourth loan with MFP and expects to make her payments on time just like her previous loans. Her Communal Bank is a cheerful group and the members are always agreeable during their meetings. With her loan of 1000 soles, Doris will buy a large quantity of high-quality wood so that she can make new coffins.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase wood for making coffins

loans.name: Milton Antonio

texts.es:
En el mercado Mayoreo de la ciudad de Managua, el joven Milton Antonio M. solicitó un crédito para invertirlo directamente en la compra de los granos básicos ya que este es el producto que él ofrece en su establecimiento donde vende arroz, maíz, frijoles, aceite, entre otros.

Se ha destacado por ser muy trabajador y también por esforzarse por desarrollar el negocio. Espera que su crédito sea otorgado satisfactoriamente y así mejorar las condiciones del negocio.

loans.use: Compra de los granos básicos

loans.name: Ireen Nekesa

texts.en:
Ireen Nekesa O. has run a school called the Springs of Life School for two years. She employs four teachers and one cook. Her primary challenges are that many parents do not understand the value of an education and others cannot afford the fees. She is using her loan of 20,000 KES to build another classroom. 

Ireen is married with four children, ranging from a five-year-old boy to an eighteen-year-old girl. She describes herself as hardworking and honest, and supplements her income by baking birthday and wedding cakes. Ireen's goals for the school are to extend its offering to class eight, grow to five hundred pupils, and be known as one of the best schools in Kenya.

loans.use: To build another classroom

loans.name: Rozia Group

texts.en:
This is Rozia group. It has four female members. These women would like to progress and develop their businesses.
Rozia is the group leader. She has a beauty salon and is busy working there in order to support her husband and five of her children who are students. Using the loan she plans to purchase more new design cosmetics for her beauty salon to expand it and attract more clients.
Maleha wants to use her loan to buy the materials for carpet weaving so she can have more good quality ones. She buys one kilo of her materials for 1500 Afghani.
Sohila tailors in her house. She has arranged a small room where she sews different kinds of clothes and has a good number of clients. Using the loan she wants to buy an electric sewing machine because she has lots of problems using her old one.
The last member, Latifa, wants a loan for her husband’s general store because he needs to buy the things which are not available in his shop.
They all have requested a group loan of 56000 Afghani.
They would like to mention the effectiveness of the Kiva process and its positive effect on their business progress.

loans.use: Expanding their businesses

loans.name: Mouv

texts.en:
Mrs. Mouv S. is a resident of Srae Vong village in Takeo province. Her husband, Mr. Lach Phan, is a laborer who earns a small income. She has six children; one is a teacher, and the others are attending the local school. Her husband is on the left in the photo.  

Mrs. Mouv S. is a farmer who owns a 0.4 hectare field on which she cultivates rice to earn a living. Her business faces a small problem because she does not have enough money to buy fertilizers to make her crops more productive. Thus, Mrs. Mouv S. has decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for her crops

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida T. is from the village of Aurora. She is 41 years old. Zenaida is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Zenaida owns & operates a business planting & harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Zenaida has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Zenaida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zenaida is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Zenaida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Stocking up her shop

loans.name: Khun

texts.en: Khun K., 25, is married and lives with a five-year-old child in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. K. and his wife have been involved in the agriculture sector, growing morning glories for sale, since 2000 and are able to earn an income of US $8 per day. He is also a skillful fisherman using traditional fishing tools to catch fish. These activities help generate better income for the family. K. and his wife try to work hard every day to ensure a good standard of living for the family, and they are seeking to improve their businesses. In order to do this, he is requesting for a loan of US $1,000 from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. He wants to use the expected loan to purchase a motorbike and seeds to grow more morning glories for his existing customers at the market. This is his first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike and plant seeds

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica M. is from the village of Poblacion, Aurora Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 53 years old, is married and has one adult child. To make a living, Veronica owns amd operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting coconut for sale. Veronica has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Veronica joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Veronica is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the sixth loan Veronica has taken out from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Freddy Zamir

texts.es: El joven Freddy
texts.en: Young Freddy

loans.use: Purchase materials for making home improvements (zinc, cement, sand, and wood)

loans.name: Chhun

texts.en: Chhun R., age 57, is married and resides with her husband and child in Takeo Province, Cambodia.  She sells fish, earning approximately $5 per day. Chhun is able to cover her family expenses.  She has been in business since 2001.  Her husband is a farmer, earning an income of $3 per day.  Chhun wants a loan to expand her business.  She is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase more fish for resale.  This is her first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: Buy more fish for resale

loans.name: Phon

texts.en: Mrs. Phon T. is 67 years old and lives with other family members in Siem Reap province. She is a married housewife who is blessed with four children. All of them are married and live independently. To earn a daily living, Phon T. plants crops as well as raises a few pigs in a pigpen next to her house. She has a life partner in her husband who assists her in this business. In order to earn extra profits, Phon T. has requested a loan to purchase additional pig foods and piglets to breed.

loans.use: To purchase pig food and piglets to breed

loans.name: Jona's Group

texts.en: Jona C.'s main source of income comes from selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in her community. She is 31 years old, married and has five school-age children. They are from the village of Balatacan, Tangub City. Jona has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Jona joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Jona is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her second loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family. Jona is the leader of a three member group accessing a loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members, if someone is delinquent or defaults. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Aïda

texts.en: Aïda N. is 47 years old, married and the mother of two. She has been a member of the "Banc Villageois" NIANING SANTHIE for two years and has always paid back her loans. She runs a tailor shop and wants to use this loan to buy new fabrics. The revenue from her business allows her to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics

loans.name: Ngaeth

texts.en: Mrs. Ngaeth P., 48, is a villager who lives in Boeng Khpob village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she grows crops to earn for a living for her family. However, she does not have enough money to support her farming. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide, and gasoline to support her farm. Her husband, Mr. Kry Srin, sells candy to earn a small income to support his family. This couple has four children; one is a farm laborer, two are students who also support their mother's farm, while the youngest one is 2 years old. Her husband is on the right of the picture.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide and gasoline.

loans.name: Rosa Argentina

texts.es: Rosa Argentina tiene 40 años de edad. Tiene 3 hijos que están menores de edad a su cargo. Ella se dedica a la actividad económica de venta de comida. Hace más de 8 años que inicio por sus hermanas ya que anteriormente, ellas se dedicaban al negocio, pues ella disfruta mucho este trabajo porque sus clientes disfrutan sus deliciosos platillos, Rosa ha logrado salir adelante a pesar de la competencia, pero siempre está recibiendo a sus clientes con una gran sonrisa. El financiamiento es para la compra de granos básicos, frutas, verduras, bolsas y cubiertos entre otras cosas.
texts.en:
Rosa Argentina is 40 years old. She is responsible for her 3 young children. For a living, she sells food. Over 8 years ago, her sisters started the business which they enjoyed greatly because their customers derived so much pleasure from the delicious meals. Rosa has been able to succeed despite the competition, and she always greets her customers with a big smile. Among other items, the loan will be use to buy basic grains, fruit, vegetables, bags, and cutlery.

Translated from Spanish by Emma Felten, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Rattna

texts.en:
Mrs. Rattna M. is a 27-year-old villager who lives in Chumrov village in the Takeo province. She and her husband Mr. Muth Mark are silk weavers who can earn a small income to support their family. Aside from weaving, Mrs. Rattna M. breeds pigs at her home. For supporting both businesses, Mrs. Rattna M. decided to ask for a loan to buy more silk and to buy piglets and pig food.
